title: v versus t graph and total energy

content.question: A <math alttext="2 kilograms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext> </mtext><mi>k</mi><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> block is placed at the top of an incline and released from rest near Earth’s surface and unknown distance <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> above the ground. The angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between the ground and the incline is also unknown. Frictional forces between the block and the incline are considered to be negligible. The block eventually slides to the bottom of the incline after <math alttext="0.75 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.75</mn><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. The block’s velocity <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></math> as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the graph starting from the instant it is released. How could a student use the graph to determine the total energy of the block-Earth system?

choices.label: Use <math alttext="m g y sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi><mi>g</mi><mi>y</mi><msub><mrow><mo>⁢</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> with <math alttext="m equals 2 kilograms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext> </mtext><mi>k</mi><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> equal to the area bound between the horizontal axis and the curve.

Use <math alttext="one half m, times v sub f squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>m</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mstyle></math> with <math alttext="m equals 2 kilograms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext> </mtext><mi>k</mi><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="v sub f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> equal to the final velocity of the object that can be found from the graph.

Use <math alttext="F d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> with <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> equal to the normal force exerted on the block and <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> equal to the area bound between the horizontal axis and the curve.
The answer cannot be determined without knowing the initial height of the object above the ground.

content.answer: Use <math alttext="one half m, times v sub f squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>m</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mstyle></math> with <math alttext="m equals 2 kilograms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext> </mtext><mi>k</mi><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="v sub f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> equal to the final velocity of the object that can be found from the graph.
